Jeremy, you want to give us an overview of what those two topics are and how they relate? JEREMY:Â  Sure. Roda basically is a routing tree web framework. So in other words, itâ€™s a toolkit for building web frameworks that route web requests using a tree. So, Rodaâ€™s core is basically just the router. But Roda uses a plugin system that is similar to Sequelâ€™s plugin system where all the additional features are contained as separate plugin modules. So, when you are building your app using Roda you basically pick only the plugins that you need and you donâ€™t load the other plugins. And by choosing which plugins you specifically need, youâ€™re basically creating a web framework custom tailored to your application. So, Rodaâ€™s history can be traced back to Rum which was a request router written by Christian Neukirchen, the author of Rack, back in 2009. And the fundamental difference between Rum and other approaches to routing was that Rum handles routing at an instance level. So, instead of passing a request to a router and having the router just point you to the request handler, in Rum the router is integrated with the request handler. And as you are routing a request you can also be handling a request. And the main advantage to integrating routing with request handling is that in most applications the URL structure somewhat reflects the application structure. So, as soon as certain branches in the routing tree are taken, you can immediately start handling the request before youâ€™ve even finished routing your request. And this allows you to easily share behavior for all routes under a given branch from a tree. It provides a natural way to DRY up your code without [littering] it with before filters. And it reduces the amount of indirection when youâ€™re routing, which in addition to being faster also makes the resulting code easier to read and understand. CORALINE:Â  So basically, you can scope instance variables and have their logic there for an entire branch of the tree, of the routing tree? JEREMY:Â  Yes, thatâ€™s one of the advantages to it. DAVID:Â  I love that itâ€™s a toolkit for a framework. How did you write this thing without just quoting Xzibit the entire time? [Laughter] DAVID:Â  Yo, dawg. I heard you like frameworks. So, we got you a framework for your framework so that you can rap while you route. JEREMY:Â  Well, originally it wasnâ€™t designed to be a toolkit. It was basically just its own framework. Some of the history, it originally came back from Rum. But in between there was what this one framework called Cuba, which I think you guys had the author of Cuba Michel Martens on earlierâ€¦ CHUCK:Â  Yup, we did. JEREMY:Â  I think back in November. And Roda basically was forked from Cuba basically due to philosophical differences between his approach to writing a web framework and the way I wanted to go. I basically was proposing patches to Cuba that he did not want to take. So, I just basically did it the open source way. If you donâ€™t like it, you fork. And thatâ€™s what I did. So, after Iâ€™ve worked, originally it was just going to be a web framework. And I thought, â€œWell, depending on what plugins you load with this, itâ€™s really going to result in a very different framework.â€ You can have a framework look significantly different depending on with plugins you load. So, thatâ€™s why I call the framework toolkit. So basically, depending which plugins you load youâ€™re basically building your own custom framework. CORALINE:Â  What are some of those plugins youâ€™re talking about? JEREMY:Â  For example, if you want a Sinatra-like API where you basically just define routes sort of like in a list, you can do that. Thereâ€™s a plugin, ClassLevelRouting, where you can have a list of the top-level routes and inside those, then you can also branch. So, you can make it so it acts just like a nested Sinatra. And there are plain plugins that change how routing occurs, like how you treat ending slashes. So, do you want to have routes that are always canonical? So, if your route ends in a slash itâ€™s treated differently than a route that does not end in a slash? The default in Roda is that theyâ€™re treated differently. So, all routes are canonical. But if you want to treat those two routes the same, thereâ€™s a plugin like empty path or something like that, that allows you to have that specific behavior. Thereâ€™s also plugins for rendering. By default, Roda is just a router. There is no plugin for rendering templates. Plenty of people use Roda as an API. So, they donâ€™t need routing of templates, I mean rendering of templates. They just need to have quick JSON API requests. So, thereâ€™s also a JSON API plugin that makes writing JSON APIs very simple. It basically can just return either a hash or an array from your route and it will be automatically converted to JSON implicitly for you, which makes writing JSON APIs really nice. Thereâ€™s also plugins for asset handling and thereâ€™s plugins for template streaming, like ActionController Live if you use that in Rails. Thereâ€™s a plugin that basically does the same thing in Roda. And thereâ€™s a lot of plugins for things that you would expect in other frameworks. Because Roda is so small, the core is so small, a lot of things that other frameworks provide are added as plugins, so that if you need them, you can load them. But if you donâ€™t need them, you donâ€™t load them and you donâ€™t pay the cost in memory and performance for using them. AVDI:Â  So, weâ€™ve had some folks on in the past to talk about Sinatra and also Padrino which is a collection of basically plugins to plug into Sinatra. How would you contrast your approach with that, with the Sinatra/Padrino ecosystem? JEREMY:Â  Well, Padrino and Sinatra are separate projects. Honestly, Iâ€™ve never worked directly on Padrino. Iâ€™ve read some of Padrinoâ€™s documentation. I looked at [maybe] a little bit of the code. But I donâ€™t have really much experience with it. But Padrino is sort of, it had sort ofâ€¦ I donâ€™t want to say, not like a Rails lite there, but adds controllers to Sinatra which arenâ€™t really Sinatra-like. Roda is actually I think more similar to Sinatraâ€™s routing in a nested level than Padrino is, especially youâ€™re defining classes. You have separate routers. With Roda basically youâ€™re just defining the routes directly like you can in Sinatra, except that you can also define routes in a nested fashion, which Sinatra doesnâ€™t allow. So, I reallyâ€¦ and Iâ€™ve used Sinatra for many years, like seven years before I started working on Roda. And really, what it is, is basically aimed at being a nice, nested Sinatra without a lot of the backwards compatibility issues that Sinatra has. AVDI:Â  Can you give an example of where nested routing is useful? JEREMY:Â  Well for example, letâ€™s say you have an albums database. So, your paths start with, your paths relate to an album. It might be like `album/some-id-for-the-album/track-list` or /update for updating it, or whatever it is. So, as soon as you take this album, as soon as you get the ID for the album, before youâ€™ve finished routing the rest of the path, you can retrieve the album from the database. And then all routes underneath that branch of the tree can share that code, which is like a before filter in other web applications. But itâ€™s sort of built in. Itâ€™s implicit. Thereâ€™s no indirection. Itâ€™s basically right there in your routing tree. So, it makes it much easier to read the code and understand what itâ€™s doing versus before filters where youâ€™re looking all over your app, where is this defined? Especially if you use Rails with controllers that inherit from each other, itâ€™s often confusing where things are happening. This makes it much more direct and you can exactly see. You can basically read the routing tree from top to bottom and see exactly where code is getting executed. There is no indirection in that case. AVDI:Â  That makes a lot of sense. JEREMY:Â  Well, thereâ€™s actuallyâ€¦ because you can basically have a block that breaks across multiple files in Ruby, thereâ€™s a plugin called MultiRoute which basically takes your routing tree and you can by plugins, or sorry, by prefixes of the path you can basically say, â€œOkay, all routes that start with albums, use this separate branch.â€ So, youâ€™d basically, when youâ€™re defining your routing tree, you do route and you give it a prefix. And then in your main app you can just do â€˜r.multi_routeâ€™ and that will dispatch all of your routes, basically your separate route prefixes, using a single regular expression to catch the route and then dispatches right to that. So, in addition to being fast it also allows you a way to break up your code into separate files. And you can use this in a nested fashion. So, if you have a very large routing tree, you can have the top-level files. So, you have the â€˜r.multi_routeâ€™ in the main app dispatch to all the main top-level prefixes. And those prefixes can then dispatch to sub-prefixes. So, this allows for building apps of arbitrary complexity while still retaining the same model of basically using this routing tree. CHUCK:Â  I could see this being used for something similar to what we see engines used for these days. So, you could have a blog app or set of routes that behave in a particular way. JEREMY:Â  Yeah, so basically you can do it that way. Also, if your blog is a separate Rack application you can also just dispatch directly to that. And you can use Roda the same way. CORALINE:Â  So, youâ€™re saying that the routing tree really has a positive impact on performance? JEREMY:Â  Yeah. Roda is actually one of the fastest web frameworks for Ruby. And thereâ€™s two parts to this. One is the request overhead is kept extremely low compared to most other web frameworks. And internally the way routing is handled is also very fast. So, the benchmarking Iâ€™ve done, I have not found, for any significant application of significant complexity, the case where other approaches to routing are faster. CHUCK:Â  So, youâ€™ve benchmarked this against Rails? JEREMY:Â  Well, yeah. And Rails is hard, because Rails has so much overhead for every request that even though the Rails router is actually very good, tenderlove wrote it, itâ€™s extremely fast and good at what it does. But thereâ€™s a ton of overhead in Rails. If you want the Rails router to use a lighter web framework thereâ€™s actually a web framework called NYNY that takes Railsâ€™ router and uses it in that. CHUCK:Â  Is there a place where people can actually go see the benchmarks? JEREMY:Â  Yeah, actually I have a project on GitHub called r10k. And so, it turns out to be very difficult to do any kind of streaming. Rack really wants you to basically come up with your whole response and then feed that out. One case is the template streaming. So, in the Rack spec basically you can return as the body of the application anything that responds to â€˜eachâ€™. So, in a lot of cases in frameworks, this is just like an array with one string inside of it. And thatâ€™s basically the entire body. But you can have an enumerable, like any enumerable really. As long as it yields strings when called with â€˜eachâ€™ it basically operates efficiently. So, thereâ€™s two ways that Roda does this. One is it has a template streaming plugin. So, you can stream templates using Transfer-Encoding chunked so you donâ€™t have to prepare the entire response before yielding to the user. This allows you to basically flesh your head part of your request before your entire request is finished generating so that the user can load the assets necessary to display the page before the page is even finished rendering. And you can be retrieving objects from the database while the client is loading the assets related to the page, which makes actual performance for the user in the browser significantly faster. The other part is streaming. Thereâ€™s two parts to streaming. One is using things like event source. So, thereâ€™s a streaming plugin in Roda now that you can stream things like doing event source type stuff. One thing that Roda doesnâ€™t have support for yet is WebSockets. And that way in the future, it will be usable by Roda to basically use Ruby both through your frontend and through your backend. So basically, you donâ€™t have to use JavaScript on the frontend and Ruby on the backend. You can use Ruby for both. And I think thatâ€™s sort of where I want Ruby to go. It was actually available in Sequel before I took Sequel over back in 2008. And I think itâ€™s an extremely well-designed plugin ecosystem where a plugin is basically just a module. And inside the module it has a module called ClassMethods if you want to add class methods, and a module called InstanceMethods if you want to add instance methods. And then for Sequel thereâ€™s a module called dataset methods. So, you can add methods just [for] the dataset class. In Roda, that doesnâ€™t make sense. So, the options for modules inside the plugin are ClassMethods and InstanceMethods. But also, RequestClassMethods and RequestInstanceMethods, and response class methods and response instance methods. So, your plugins can basically, each Roda class that you have creates a custom subclass of the request class and response class specific to your Roda app class. So, when you subclass Roda app it also subclasses the request and response classes, and that way when you apply plugins they apply the plugins only to that request class or that response class. And that way you can customâ€¦ you basically modify any part of your request, your response, or your current scope, add methods, and you can always call super to get the default behavior. AVDI:Â  I guess part of what makes that approach work is that you have a prettyâ€¦ youâ€™ve limited the number of objects that might need to be extended by a plugin. Is that a fair statement? JEREMY:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s certainly the case. I think thatâ€™s my approach in general. I donâ€™t tend to have a whole bunch of different objects. I generally tend to stick mostly to the primitives and then only have objects for things that really need to be objects. So, in Sequel thereâ€™s the database. Thereâ€™s the dataset. Thereâ€™s the model. Those are the three main objects that you deal with in Sequel. In Roda itâ€™s going to be the scope, which is actually the instance of the Roda class that youâ€™re using. And thereâ€™s the request and the response. And there are other classes used, but thereâ€™s not that many of them. In most cases youâ€™re using just those objects and the primitives. AVDI:Â  Thatâ€™s actually kind of an interesting design [inaudible] where a lot of times we shun having objects that have many, many methods, a few objects with many, many methods. But it does seem like itâ€™s true that when youâ€™re trying to do a plugin architecture, as soon as you have lots of different objects, now you have to find a way to adjust or modify or subclass or something lots of different classes in order to let the plugin advise any part of the system, right? JEREMY:Â  Yeah. And some people would say this violates the Single Responsibility Principle. And in some cases it does. But it makes the code much easier to understand. Itâ€™s much easier to understand three objects than it is to understand a hundred different types of objects. So, and especially if youâ€¦ one of my approaches is using primitives for a lot of things which people also say that might be an anti-pattern. In my experience I found it actually works very well. It keeps the code very simple because basically all Ruby programmers know how strings work. They know how arrays work. They know how hashes work. If you have separate objects for each type of thing where you could just use a more primitive type, it makes the code I think harder for newcomers to understand. I think it is much easier to understand code that basically has a few object types that you need to understand. But the rest of it is primitives that you can just use. And if you find later that your primitives donâ€™t do what you need, you can always in Ruby subclass the primitives and add methods to them. So, in Sequel originally the association reflections were just hashes. And eventually it became subclasses of hashes with basically added methods to them. So, if you make objects for all those things before you really need them, I think you end up making your application or your library significantly more complex. AVDI:Â  It almost feels like maybe there are different forces at work for library code or framework code than there are for say domain code where you might want more objects. JEREMY:Â  I think I agree with that. I try to keep especially libraries, should be kept as simple as possible. Because you donâ€™t know exactly how a library is going to be used all over the place. So, applications I think should be treated differently than libraries are treated, both in testing and in design. CORALINE:Â  How would people go about writing and taking advantage of the plugin architecture in Roda? Do you have third-party groups or individuals who are contributing plugins as well? JEREMY:Â  Thereâ€™s certainly a lot more of the internal plugins that I have linked as external plugins. And then there are probably quite a few people that work in external plugins. And every time someone works an external plugin, I try to get them to send me the link so I can include it in Rodaâ€™s documentation so that people know about not just the internal plugins but the external plugins as well. And in both Rodaâ€™s and Sequelâ€™s plugin architecture, itâ€™s designed so that it doesnâ€™t matter to the user if a plugin is internal or external. Itâ€™s treated and loaded exactly the same way. CHUCK:Â  Yeah. I just want to point out. When he says internal versus external, Iâ€™ll put a link in the show notes to this. Because then theyâ€™re tested alongside the main lib code so that you can be sure that no part of any modifications youâ€™re doing to the library are going to break the plugin code. Youâ€™re testing all the plugins that Roda uses as well. And this makes it so you can change things and make sureâ€¦ you donâ€™t want to change things thatâ€™ll break external plugins. JEREMY:Â  Great. CORALINE:Â  One of the things you talked about in the documentation for Roda is application freezing. Can you talk about that a little bit? JEREMY:Â  Yeah. So, Roda actually, one of theâ€¦ thereâ€™s four main goals with Roda. One of them is reliability. The other ones are simplicity, extensibility, and performance. But the reliability part comes in part from freezing the app. So, the idea is in production you have a frozen application. And this freezes all of the internal data structures except for the thread-safe caches. So, that makes it basically eliminate all possible thread safety issues when using the framework, even when youâ€™re running on Ruby implementations that lack a global VM lock, like JRuby and Rubinius. A lot of other Ruby web applications that are thread-safe are thread-safe on MRI because they rely on things like accessing a hash from multiple threads being thread-safe due to the global VM lock. On JRuby and Rubinius, theyâ€™re not thread-safe. You can actually see this on a few, recently about Oga which is an XML parser for Ruby. And itâ€™s basically designed to replace Nokogiri because on Rubinius Nokogiri doesnâ€™t work correctly, because it relies on the global VM lock for handling thread safety issues. So, if youâ€™re doing multiple thread work using Nokogiri on Rubinius, it crashes because it doesnâ€™t synchronize correctly. In Oga, they use a Ruby way that works correctly. So, in any case, Roda is designed so that thread safety is critical so that you can run this in JRuby and itâ€™ll be extremely fast. And one of the reasons it has to run, it has to be completely thread-safe is JRuby is concurrent. So, you canâ€™t rely on the global VM lock to handle your thread synchronization. So, it basically handles that for you. And it does this by freezing the internal data structures so that if you attempted to use them in a thread-unsafe manner, like letâ€™s say you try to write to them, youâ€™ll basically get an instant exception because theyâ€™re all frozen. So, thatâ€™s basically the approach to thread safety. So, in testing and production you run it frozen. And then in development you can run with the reloader so itâ€™s not frozen. You can still update things. AVDI:Â  To make this more concrete for listeners, can you give an example of the kind of thing that somebody might try to access and then find that itâ€™s frozen? JEREMY:Â  Yeah. One of the things you often see if youâ€™re on Stack Overflow looking at things like Sinatra is that people will try to do something that should be run globally like before. For example, Sequel database setup, people will do that for every request that comes in and figure out, â€œWhy am I leaking connections?â€ You try to do something like that. Letâ€™s say youâ€™re loading a plugin for example but youâ€™re trying to load a plugin inside a request. Itâ€™ll fail because when you freeze the application you basically canâ€™t load any more plugins into it because itâ€™s frozen. That sort of thing where if you do it, youâ€™ll get an instant exception, and that way youâ€™ll know that what youâ€™re doing is a bad idea. And you can basically fix it.
